awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Integrated Laboratory and Field Studies of Organic Nitrates from BVOC + NO3:  Formation, Processing, and Fates
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is focused on establishing a fundamental understanding of the formation, processing, and fate of nitrogen compounds in the atmosphere. A series of laboratory chamber experiments will be performed to study the reactions of nitrogen compounds with volatile gases from biogenic sources. The results will lead to a better understanding of the formation of very small particles in the atmosphere that are relevant to air quality and climate.

The objectives of the proposed research are to (1) To experimentally map out the effects of different environmental factors (humidity, temperature, particle acidity) on the formation of organic nitrate (ON) from biogenic volatile organic compounds (BVOC) and NO3; (2) To determine the changes in gas-particle partitioning and properties of ON with dark aging and photochemical aging; and (3) To characterize ON and the formation of secondary organic aerosol from BVOC+NO3 and assess their fates in a region of high BVOC/anthropogenic emissions.
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The project investigated the formation, processing, and fates of organic nitrates formed from nitrate radical oxidation of biogenic volatile organic compounds. Organic nitrates are ubiquitous in ambient environments but there is a limited understanding regarding their lifecycles in the atmosphere. In this study, we conducted laboratory chamber studies to investigate secondary organic aerosol (SOA) and organic nitrate formation from monoterpenes (a-pinene, b-pinene, limonene), as well as the hydrolysis and photolysis of organic nitrates. We also conducted field measurements in Atlanta - a region with high anthropogenic and biogenic emissions - to investigate the sources and processing of organic nitrates.

The nitrate radical oxidation of a-pinene, b-pinene, limonene are efficient reactions to generate organic nitrates. We determined the hydrolysis and photolysis fates of monoterpene organic nitrates. We found that the hydrolyzable fraction of organic nitrates formed from daytime vs. nighttime chemistry differs, in which the latter have a smaller hydrolyzable fraction. For organic nitrates that undergo hydrolysis, the hydrolysis lifetimes were determined to be much shorter than previously reported. We further constrained the hydrolysis lifetimes and mechanisms by synthesizing authentic monoterpene nitrate standards with different functional groups. In terms of photolysis, we quantified the photolysis lifetimes of monoterpene nitrates and demonstrated that photolysis is an important atmospheric sink for monoterpene nitrates and can lead to the formation of ozone. We also conducted mixture experiments - simultaneous or sequential oxidation of multiple volatile organic compounds - and showed non-linear effects in SOA formation and composition. Results from these fundamental laboratory studies provide the critically needed experimentally constrained parameters for chemical transport models to accurately evaluate the role of organic nitrates in nitrogen budget, and formation of ozone and organic aerosols.

From the field deployments, we found that about 85% of the non-refractory species in PM2.5 are in the PM1 in Atlanta. We observed notable SOA and organic nitrate formation from both daytime photooxidation and nighttime nitrate radical oxidation chemistry. Monoterpenes were found to be the most important SOA precursors at night. Further, we observed significant contributions from highly oxidized acid-like compounds to the aged SOA. Taken together, these results demonstrate the prevalence of biogenic organic nitrates in ambient environments and provide new insights into their sources and properties.

This project also contributed to development of a kinetic model to simulate the formation and evaporation of SOA from nitrate radical oxidation of monoterpenes, understanding of fragmentation patterns of compounds in advanced mass spectrometry measurements of organic aerosols, as well as several collaborative studies on characterizations of organic aerosol composition and properties.

The research supported by this project contributed to the training of graduate and undergraduate students from the School of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, School of Earth and Atmospheric Sciences, and School of Civil and Environmental Engineering. Research outcomes have been disseminated via conference presentations, journal publications, book chapters, a workshop of "Nitrate Radicals and Biogenic Volatile Organic Compounds: Oxidation, Mechanisms, and Organic Aerosol", as well as shared with undergraduate and graduate students in relevant courses. Results from this project provide new fundamental laboratory and ambient data to represent monoterpene organic nitrate formation and fates in atmospheric models, which would allow for more accurate predictions of the impacts of organic nitrates on NOx cycling, ozone, and SOA formation.

The education program is an important component of the project.  We developed a "Particulate Matter and Air Pollution" middle school program and hosted summer teacher training workshops. Topics included fundamental concepts related to particulate matter and air pollution, how to use low-cost aerosol sensors and interpret data. Each teacher was provided with a full lecture plan and an education kit (with all necessary materials and supplies) needed for implementation of the program at their schools.
